I like to play KSP with a fairly realistic approach in mind, and because of this, I don't prefer to just 'cheat' or set max debris to zero, or other such methods of removing debris. So with that said, and with the serious lack of updated (as of at least 1.0) threads on this topic, would anyone care to share their methods for removing debris and sending it down to the body it's orbiting (efficiently, and without much difficulty)? I'm playing career by the way. I also would greatly prefer to be able to recover the funds associated with these pieces of debris.

I have the StageRecovery mod installed (and every single piece of debris is setup with chutes and could be recovered this way), which is awesome, but it doesn't ever seem able to save anything if it has to go through reentry. As a side question, does anyone know how to fix this? I can't put heat shields on all of this debris, and pretty much any stages that aren't jettisoned before orbit and must undergo reentry, always end up not being recovered. Everything usually burns up on reentry.

Even if I'm unable to recover any funds, I would like to start removing debris from orbit; I think it's starting to affect my computer's performance with all that extra stuff up there. As for suggestions, please keep in mind that all of the debris that I'm trying to deorbit has no docking ports. I assume I will need to use the Klaw (creating a bay for capturing the debris inside my ship sounds much harder, more expensive and inefficient, and I don't think I even have the parts necessary w/o additional parts mods).

Thanks KSP community!

 

Edit: Forgot to add, I found this thread pretty useful and relevant, but I just don't understand how I can successfully recover these stages properly, for the funds and everything. Some of this debris has expensive engines I'd like to recover, not just empty fuel tanks.

Edited March 12, 2016 by KocLobster

The easiest way to clean up debris is not to create the debris in the first place. 

This is actually not too hard to do-- it's a matter of careful attention to ship design.

The biggest source of debris is the stuff you do repeatedly (like going from the surface to LKO, and maybe shuttling back and forth between Kerbin/Mun/Minmus).  So work out a set of designs for those procedures that leave no debris behind, and you're good.

For example, when launching to LKO:  Simply make sure that the only stage that achieves orbit is the final one.  As long as every stage prior to the final one is jettisoned while you're still on a suborbital trajectory, then it'll naturally fall back down and take care of itself.  For me, this is isn't hard to do because it's what my three-stage-to-orbit designs tend to end up doing naturally, even when I'm not particularly trying to avoid debris.  My first stage is usually SRBs, the second stage gets my Ap up to about where I want it, and the third stage is orbital insertion.

For cases where your final stage becomes debris after it finishes its mission-- for example, a fuel-delivery tanker, after it has arrived at your orbiting depot and divested itself of its load-- all you need to do is keep a wee bit of fuel left over so they can deorbit themselves.

This is a lot easier to do if your primary staging location is fairly low down, like 90-120 km.  Some people like to keep their space stations in higher orbits, but if you do that, you'll have  more issues with debris, because it takes more dV to deorbit from such altitudes, and "accidental" orbits are easier.

If you're sending ships to the Mun or Minmus and need a disposable stage to go from LKO to your Mun/Minmus ejection:  just set it up so that it gets staged away when you're on a collision course with the target, then after you jettison you can do a minor course correction to fix up your path.

You'll also make your life simpler if you forget about trying to recover the debris and just focus on getting rid of it.  That's what I do.  There's little economic incentive to recover it, and taking that constraint away makes life easier.  However, if you have your own reasons for wanting to recover the stuff, of course you can do that, but in that case I'm probably not the right person to offer advice.

Thanks Snark, you always make the best posts. I will take to heart that it just simply isn't worth it to recover the debris for money, and instead should just dispose of it. I have certainly read before that it's a lot easier to just design things to not even produce debris in the first place, but I always end up doing so anyways,

1 hour ago, Snark said:

If you're sending ships to the Mun or Minmus and need a disposable stage to go from LKO to your Mun/Minmus ejection:  just set it up so that it gets staged away when you're on a collision course with the target, then after you jettison you can do a minor course correction to fix up your path.

I love this, I never thought of this, but seems it's a very easy way to ensure debris stops piling up around the Mun. 

What I don't understand is how exactly to design things to not create debris. I often end up with a stage that gets me in an LKO, but theres enough fuel left to not warrant throwing it away right before I achieve that LKO. Often, however, there is also not enough fuel to get it to crash into the Mun. There seems to be no middle ground, and I end up with debris that has very strange orbits around Kerbin. I guess I need to play with and tweak dV even more so than I already do now, to ensure stages are empty of fuel at the right time, so they can be detached before orbit or into a planet/moon?

3 minutes ago, KocLobster said:

What I don't understand is how exactly to design things to not create debris.

I would suggest a combination of an informative mod (KER or MechJeb) with a "subway map" style dV map. Then just design each stage to have just under or just over the dV required for the next step. 

For instance, I usually make it so my first stage has ~1400 Dv, second has ~900 (so that those both are suborbital when I stage) and if I'm going to Mun, third stage has ~900. This lets me, like Snark said, to have the Munar injection stage crash into the Mun, and the lander/return stage makes a minor course change to not crash.

I use both, as well as dV maps. Thank you for the suggestion though; I will start doing this so I don't have any more debris created. I'll have to use the Klaw to get rid of the current debris I have.

51 minutes ago, KocLobster said:

I often end up with a stage that gets me in an LKO, but theres enough fuel left to not warrant throwing it away right before I achieve that LKO. Often, however, there is also not enough fuel to get it to crash into the Mun. There seems to be no middle ground, and I end up with debris that has very strange orbits around Kerbin.

This is doable, too.  Let's say you're in LKO and about to head to the Mun, which takes around 850 m/s of dV.  Suppose that the stage you currently have is around 500 m/s, i.e. if you stage it when you run out of fuel, it'll end up in an eccentric orbit with a high cis-munar Ap and a Pe that's down in LKO.

Okay, so, when the time comes to stage it, just tweak your trajectory a little smidgeon radially outward, which will lower your Kerbin Pe (behind you) below, say, 20 km.  Then stage it.  It will coast up to Ap, then come back around and burn up in Kerbin's atmosphere.

Another approach to avoid oddball debris in the Mun-Kerbin milk run is to use dedicated single-stage transfer ships.  These are craft that are designed to shuttle between LKO and low Munar orbit, without ever landing on either body.  So your trip to the Mun from Kerbin's surface would look like this:  launch from surface to your orbiting space station in LKO.  There you dock it to a tug (ideally, something nuclear-powered to give a good Isp).  The tug takes the ship to Mun orbit and undocks, then the ship can land itself.  You can have a station in low Mun orbit, and a fuel-mining setup to keep the station well supplied with fuel.

Note that if you keep a fuel station in LKO, that's a handy way to reduce debris, too-- when you get up to LKO, you dock to the station and either take on any needed fuel or dump extra fuel.  Helps to let you precisely tune your dV to what you want it to be, by onloading/offloading fuel without wasting any.

NO WAIT!!!!  Don't get rid of your debris I just started a challenge to use all this debris to make new stuff using KIS/KAS

There is no "reputation" or "reputation power" anymore-- that was a feature of the old forums.

What we have now is "likes", which you give by clicking the "Like this" button.  You can see each person's "like count" (i.e. how many times someone else has liked that person's stuff) next to the little green "+" icon under their name.  When you like someone's post, they get +1 to this, regardless of who you are.

The system caps you to liking no more than 25 posts a day, to limit abuse of the system.
